comments.commentBody:
"The elite were protected and the banks were rescued,"

Is that a fact? Perhaps you can supply some evidence?

That's called increasing the money supply. It's not really what we needed but when Congress can't do anything but cut taxes and spending, that's about all we had. If we hadn't had it, we would probably be flirting with unemployment (standard measure) of well over 15% right now, a depressed stock market and a GDP heading south.
Stimulus involves increasing demand by spending money. When the government does it, it involves increasing deficit spending over a relatively short period in order to "stimulate" the production of goods and services and hiring. [Get it? stimulus has something to do with stimulating the economy).
As far as i can tell, Prof. Krugman has used his terms consistently. If you go to his blog, you will frequently see his approach reduced to numbers, stats and formulas, if that's what you want.

"debt forgiveness would merely wipe the slate clean to begin again the short march into crisis"

Great point. Debt foregiveness would speed a recovery. It is not sufficient in itself to solve the underlying problems. Those must be done too.

Debt is merely the score when the music stopped on the bubble. It is unfair. Restarting the music is not the answer, even if the unfairness of that moment is fixed.
The Bubble hid from us what we were doing. When it popped, it was dropped on us fully formed. Now we need to face it, and our politicians are owned by those who don't want that to happen.

We have a reign of false prosperity in America based on credit. The vast majority of citizens, those in the lower 2/3rds of the economy, can't afford the American lifestyle because wages and other sources of income haven't kept up with inflation over the last couple of decades or so. The solution is to buy on credit and hope for the best.

Seen from another angle, the loose credit for mortgages and other loans up to 2008 was an effort by the moneyed class to trap a greater share of the population into long term indebtedness which, at its worst. is a transfer program of wealth from the middle class to those with capital, the upper 5% of wealth holders. It didn't work. In fact, it backfired because the money handlers, banks and mortgage firms, were more anxious to book the loans than to carry out their responsibilities to assure the loans were sound.

We are a society out of balance in a world that knows no boundaries to the flow of money seeking greater returns. We have not restored that balance, merely postponed the reckoning. Too much cash is flowing to the upper one quarter, too much debt is being piled on the middle half and too much exploitation, by high interest rates, etc., is being shoved at the bottom quarter. A job that paid 42,000 in 1988 needs to pay 84,000 today to reflect the current value of money. Business, stockholders and the wealthy short change workers and pocket the difference. False prosperity must, eventually, fall.

My model of the financial markets is based upon the notion that the central banks are engaged in a pyramid scheme using the debt/equity/derivatives markets. According to this model, there must be exponential growth in the financial system or the markets will crash.
Leveraged growth may be fueled by monetary injections, interest rate cuts, credit expansion, balance sheet expansions, higher multiples on earnings, currency weakness, tax increases, population increases, real economic growth, etc.
Each of these parameters has real limits, e.g., interest rates are hard to cut once they reach zero, populations that are aging and falling into poverty tend to see declining birth rates, etc.
If I am correct, the central banks have no conceivable exit strategy that does not entail unrealistic growth expectations. Monetary policy is reaching its limits. So, what's the new plan?
From where I sit, the excuses for the next crash are already being mooted about in the media. In other words, there is no Plan B.
These bankers and their apologists were too corrupt to see the obvious solutions that existed. Instead, hard working, thrifty people who try to save and avoid debt are criticized for their virtue...virtue is now bad, you see.
Newspeak at its finest...financially teetering, morally bankrupt leaders trying to corrupt the people in order to cover up their own turpitude.

Actually, economic history shows rather clearly that creditors who have been burned indeed start lending again when times get better. Without that willingness, the boom-bust cycle from 1815 to 1929 would never have taken place, after all. In a hard-money gold-standard economy, creditors have no recourse when debtors are bankrupt: the bank is broken, there are no assets to recover anyway. But a few year later, banks are happily lending again, no?

So RHM's seemingly 'rational' response turns out to be simply and flatly historically wrong. But it _sounds_ so reasonable...just like German austerity policies _sound_ so reasonable, and the desire for money of fixed value _feels_ so reasonable.

This kind of common sense reasonableness, unfortunately, is about as useful in the real world as the common-sense reasonableness of Aristotelian physics, which said that a cannonball fell faster than a feather. Keynsian macroeconomics is to this kind of commonsense as Galileo was to Aristotelian physics.

Using whitewashing language, Krugman never discusses the ugly side of "forgiving" debt. Forgiving sounds like such a virtuous act. Unfortunately, there aren't any real "forgivers". There are creditors who are forced, usually by government, to give up collecting debts that are owed them. You cannot call this "forgiveness". I'd love Mr. Krugman to explain how an economy recovers from the creditors being burned. Will those creditors willingly jump in and loan to others again? Or will they decide the risk is too great that the government "forgivers" will come in and pull the rug out from under them again? Isn't this part of the problem we are already facing today, with banks being skittish about loaning to small businesses? This is one of the most heavily regulated industries in the country. Piling on more government strong-arming, and we'll see even more banks bow out of the financial industry. I know it is avant-garde to hate banks, and talk of sticking it to them. Seems ill-advised as a long-game strategy for the economy.

Right. We could reinstitute the Jubilee Year, when property reverted to its original owners and debts were forgiven. See also re the institution of the "prozbul" by Hillel about two thousand years ago, which modified the forgiving of debts in what was by then no longer a mainly agricultural society.

In the ancient world, having periods of debt forgiveness was recognized as necessary to maintain the proper functioning of society. It's even found in the Old Testament. Can it be that today's leaders are less competent at handling a debt crisis than the Sumerians of 5,000 years ago?
That's true, unless the "contract" in question concerns the pensions of retired workers in Detroit. Then, not so much.

The idea of tariffs in the early 20th Century, by law, was to set them to offset unfairness. It was to create fair competition, not to prevent it.

Unfairly low wages, unfair government subsidy, other circumtances setting us at disadvantage, were all to be offset by a tariff set to produce fair competition.

Now, tariffs were misused. They become exclusionary. They were set for revenue instead of economic effect. But this basic idea is what we must rescue from "Free Trade" which is anything but free or fair for either side.

Yes, if what I observe in the real world is any guide, a lot of the personal debt is not people splurging on home entertainment systems and BMWs but people whose monthly paychecks do not stretch to cover clothes for growing children, car repairs, medical bills, or even groceries.

Have to underscore that statement about Hillary Clinton.

She will announce a decision at a proper time, regardless of when her decision will have been made.

Actually I don't think we really know yet, at least not from what we saw in tonight's show, if Alicia is actually going to run or not. She still has time to change her mind before the Monday deadline to announce. Her "firm" decision to run seemed influenced largely by the PAC, but now that she knows it's a fraud that could change her decision.

I also think it's amusing that a couple of weeks ago Mike Hale was complaining about what he saw as an intrusion by real life political figures in the drama, but tonight he chose to impose Hillary Clinton on his recap drawing a rather inept analogy with Alicia Florrick's indecision about running. Just for your info Mr. Hale there is a right time and a wrong time for such an announcement and it's still too early for Mrs. Clinton to be making any such announcement even if she already knows what she's going to do.

Those anti -redlining laws date from the '70s, way earlier than the boom in sub-prime lending. The idea that suddenly,  in the Bush years,  these laws would force lenders to give loans to minorities just does not make sense.  You need to look for another explanation.

I want to support Ms. Hill's comment that banks were not compelled to make bad loans; in fact, it was a long-standing practice.  My friends employed by banks told me, long before the crash, that loans to marginal borrowers were a high-profit product that was popular with management.  Such loans had higher interest rates and many marginal borrowers were actually qualified, other than having no credit record or being in an undesirable neighborhood.  The problem is that those profits were dependent on a growing middle class, which we have not had for decades.
Actually the laws from the 70's Withheld refers to never forced any bank to make a single loan. They forced banks to apply the same lending standards to everyone.

I lean left, but rational.  I listened to the far left demand that Red Lining practices be prohibited.  So banks made loans in Red Lined Districts and took an enormous hit.  Since when are they to blame when they were ordered to make loans to people who couldn't possibly make the loan payments but were needed to get a proper racial balance on the loan books.   Does Krugman really content that loans to Hispanics, Blacks and Whites all failed in proportion to their population ratios?  I'm not a Nobel Prize winner in economics, but I know darn well that some categories of mortgage recipients were and still are far less likely to be successful borrowers than others and the entire world population has been crushed by liberals demanding that  banks make unsound loans that caused havoc.

and as the word is out about the selfdestructive 'currency war' and greedy speculators, investors and bankers have overtaken AGAIN the Worlds economy - let's all see what they have learned from their effort in 2008 to take it over the cliff.

Will they be successful this time?!

"we spend money we're now stimulating the economy of China and other countries which now have our jobs courtesy of our patriotic multinational corporations and Wall Street banksters."

Any stimulus directed at middle class and below will produce a near-term improvement in the economy, but as you mention, the dollars will flow to China and other low cost manufacturers. And it won't be limited to consumer goods. Building material and food are also growing imports from China and the rest of Asia.

What very few on this board want to admit is they want to post-War golden years to return even though many of them had disdain for the consumer oriented economy that thrived in that period (some garbage about exploiting the Third World, imperialistic, neo-colonialist position the US was in during to golden years.).
The Bubble hid from us what we were doing. When it popped, it was dropped on us fully formed. Now we need to face it, and our politicians are owned by those who don't want that to happen.

Debt relief will be a viable option to improving the economy when those whose wealth prevents them from being affected by debt become convinced that they, too, will benefit from it.  That probably will correspond to a rapid and severe temperature drop in a place of supernatural heat.

Punishment is instructive to the poor. They become debtors and it does not matter why. Debt for jewelry, and sports cars is the same kind of debt incurred for student loans, paying doctor and hospital bills or by the unemployed to pay the light bill; It is all the same even if the creditor extended credit recklessly to people who they should have known could not repay but just wanted debt that they would bundle off to unsuspecting investors. No righteousness involved the creditor demand repayment in full and the law is on their side.

Most consumer debt is high interest debt. Interest is a bet on the risk they the debtor cannot pay. If a retailer buys a product for sale and puts it on his shelves and it doesn't sell, the retailer can't return the shipment to the wholesaler for a refund. He runs a sale to cut his losses. Yet institutionalized creditors do not bargain with the debtor (you owe $1,000 make 3 payments of $200 and we’ll call it square) but they sell debt at a sharp discount to ruthless debt collectors who actually add to the debt. This is the moral equivalent of settling the dogs on the hapless debtor. This is not righteousness it is contempt and superiority and a warning to the masses to remind them whose running things and we have Debtor-Creditor and draconian bankruptcy laws to prove it. Today your mortgaged home can be foreclosed and sold at auction without the property owner ever being in default and when banks are fined there is no restitution.

The impediments of morality are one of the main reasons that indirect methods are sometimes more palatable.

For example, the Comedy Party advocates Welfare for All -- giving everyone a monthly stipend, which the poor and the rich get today. That is more palatable than trying to force the poor to work when there are no jobs and to tax the inheritance of the rich. But giving everyone a trust fund accomplishes the same thing, and avoids the moral judgments on the rich and the poor. At least, it puts the same moral prism in front of everyone.

For this and other great indirect methods of improving things, go to YouTube and watch Comedy Party Platform (2 min 9 sec). Then support Elizabeth Warren and invite me to speak to your group.

Right. We could reinstitute the Jubilee Year, when property reverted to its original owners and debts were forgiven. See also re the institution of the "prozbul" by Hillel about two thousand years ago, which modified the forgiving of debts in what was by then no longer a mainly agricultural society.

The steady and prolonged decline in wages is what lead to the debt problem in the first place. Many Americans have been poor for a long time but were able to delay the day of reckoning by refinancing, HELOCs, credit cards, and payday loans.

People are smarter than banks and have started to make the adjustments, but the economy is by definition going to have less activity when income growth is restricted to the top 10%.

Debt is the symptom, greed at the top is the cause.

I agree with you about sanctions against Russia. Those are stupid and harmful in my opinion.

I disagree with you that printing money isn't going to end well, since an increased money supply can't cause problems (inflation is the problem in question here) as long as the economy can increase its capacity to accommodate the increase in the money supply. That isn't happening at this point. And once it does, the central bank has tools to deal with any inflation that results.

But it's pretty clear that German dependence - by design - on exports makes it extremely vulnerable to the economic problems of its trading partners. So the weaknesses that we now see in its trading partners - caused to a significant extent by Germany's insistence on forcing austerity on those partners in the euro zone - can only result in a reduction of orders for German products from those trading partners.

The dogma here continues to be that everybody should run surpluses, everybody should spend less than they take in, everybody should be above average. That's a nice idea, but it doesn't work mathematically.

AND at the other thread a funny commenter wrote:

'2) A condition of consolidating under the Euro could have been forcing trade balance. That is, preventing Germany from running a surplus against the periphery.'

probably meaning - 'That is, preventing the periphery from running a plus against Germany.

How crazy economics have become?

Sorry - Mr. Wilson was not upholding the law. He told the young men to walk on the sidewalk. That was the issue. I as a pedestrian often walk in the street when there is little traffic. No policeman has ever spoken to me about it.

Essentially, Mr. Wilson shot Mr. Brown because he continued to walk in the street.

Thrashed and humiliated? It looked more like Brown shoved and taunted. Furthermore, the officer had no knowledge of that incident.By selecting incendiary words, you're demonstrating just as much sentiment as you seem to decry.

This sentimental reading of the Ferguson case is based on a false analogy between White males feeling threatened by social change and Wilson's reaction to Brown. Sure, some white males don't like full equality and status for non-whites and women, especially in times of earning loss and unemployment. They feel dis-empowered and threatened by progressive social change. But Wilson was a police officer upholding the law, our law, the law we all vote for; he was not an angry white male threatened by progressive change. And Brown was not "challenging his authority" in the sense of being engaged in identity politics in the writer's sentimental idealization. He had just thrashed and humiliated a Korean grocer and stole his property and was disregarding a police officer. That of course does not justify the shooting itself, which may have violated the law and should be fully investigated.

The upper class came out of the great depression much wealthier and more powerful than when the depression started. Real wealth and power is by definition real. The Enron model is a fun game but eventual time runs out and the game is over. Yesterday's tour of our beautiful area and its many magnificent estates made one thing perfectly clear the great estates predate the Great Depression and the properties for sale seem of more recent vintage.

Her ignorant arrogance was the textbook definition of trite.  Real hunters shoot some of their own meat instead of buying it wrapped in hypocritical plastic...  and they train their dogs to obey them.

Pamela Gyyn Kripke is a double threat. She speaks animal with the same adroit aplomb she effortlessly threads humor and depth into her pithy personal essays.
My heart beating hard, I cheered for an animal I have never considered to be more than a pest -- to win it's freedom; while at the same time duly impressed with the single-minded tenacity we typically reserved for pit bulls, give that squirrel a run for her money.
I especially love how Pamela Gwen, never trite, ties a brilliant observance of the animal kingdom to the common day pluck and fortitude we all raise to, when we have no other way but up.
